metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Web Geolocation API
Locate the User's Position
The HTML Geolocation API is used to get the geographical position of a user.
content.html: The HTML Geolocation API is used to get the geographical position of a user.

content.text: Since this can compromise privacy, the position is not available unless the user approves it.
content.html: Since this can compromise privacy, the position is not available unless the user approves it.

content.text: Try It
Note
Geolocation is most accurate for devices with GPS, like smartphones.
content.html: Geolocation is most accurate for devices with GPS, like smartphones.

content.text: Browser Support
The Geolocation API is supported in all browsers:
content.html: The Geolocation API is supported in all browsers:

content.code_html: Yes Yes Yes Yes Yes

content.text: Note
The Geolocation API will only work on secure contexts such as HTTPS.
content.html: The Geolocation API will only work on secure contexts such as HTTPS.

content.text: If your site is hosted on a non-secure origin (such as HTTP) the requests to get the users location will no longer function.
content.html: If your site is hosted on a non-secure origin (such as HTTP) the requests to get the users location will no longer function.

content.text: Using the Geolocation API
The getCurrentPosition() method is used to return the user's position.
content.html: The getCurrentPosition() method is used to return the user's position.

content.text: The example below returns the latitude and longitude of the user's position:
content.html: The example below returns the latitude and longitude of the user's position:

syntaxHighlighting.text: "Geolocation is not supported by this browser."

syntax_highlighting.text: "Geolocation is not supported by this browser."

content.code_html:
<script>
const x = document.getElementById("demo");
function getLocation() {
  if (navigator.geolocation) {
    navigator.geolocation.getCurrentPosition(showPosition);
  } else {
    x.innerHTML = "Geolocation is not supported by this browser.";
  }
}

function showPosition(position) {
  x.innerHTML = "Latitude: " + position.coords.latitude +
  "<br>Longitude: " + position.coords.longitude;
}
</script>

syntax_highlighting_data.text: "Geolocation is not supported by this browser."

content.text: Example explained:
The example above is a very basic Geolocation script, with no error handling.
content.html: The example above is a very basic Geolocation script, with no error handling.

content.text: Handling Errors and Rejections
The second parameter of the getCurrentPosition() method is used to handle errors. It specifies a function to run if it fails to get the user's location:
content.html: The second parameter of the getCurrentPosition() method is used to handle errors. It specifies a function to run if it fails to get the user's location:

syntaxHighlighting.text: "The request to get user location timed out."

syntax_highlighting.text: "The request to get user location timed out."

content.code_html:
function showError(error) {
  switch(error.code) {
    case error.PERMISSION_DENIED:
      x.innerHTML = "User denied the request for Geolocation."
      break;
    case error.POSITION_UNAVAILABLE:
      x.innerHTML = "Location information is unavailable."
      break;
    case error.TIMEOUT:
      x.innerHTML = "The request to get user location timed out."
      break;
    case error.UNKNOWN_ERROR:
      x.innerHTML = "An unknown error occurred."
      break;
  }
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: "The request to get user location timed out."

content.text: Displaying the Result in a Map
To display the result in a map, you need access to a map service, like Google Maps.
content.html: To display the result in a map, you need access to a map service, like Google Maps.

content.text: In the example below, the returned latitude and longitude is used to show the location in a Google Map (using a static image):
content.html: In the example below, the returned latitude and longitude is used to show the location in a Google Map (using a static image):

content.code_html:
function showPosition(position) {
  let latlon = position.coords.latitude + "," + position.coords.longitude;

  let img_url = "https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/staticmap?center=
  "+latlon+"&zoom=14&size=400x300&sensor=false&key=YOUR_KEY";

  document.getElementById("mapholder").innerHTML = "<img src='"+img_url+"'>";
}

content.text: Location-specific Information
This page has demonstrated how to show a user's position on a map.
content.html: This page has demonstrated how to show a user's position on a map.

content.text: Geolocation is also very useful for location-specific information, like:
content.html: Geolocation is also very useful for location-specific information, like:

content.text: The getCurrentPosition() Method - Return Data
The getCurrentPosition() method returns an object on success. The latitude, longitude and accuracy properties are always returned. The other properties are returned if available:
content.html: The getCurrentPosition() method returns an object on success. The latitude, longitude and accuracy properties are always returned. The other properties are returned if available:

content.code_html:
Property Returns
coords.latitude The latitude as a decimal number (always returned)
coords.longitude The longitude as a decimal number (always returned)
coords.accuracy The accuracy of position (always returned)
coords.altitude The altitude in meters above the mean sea level (returned if available)
coords.altitudeAccuracy The altitude accuracy of position (returned if available)
coords.heading The heading as degrees clockwise from North (returned if available)
coords.speed The speed in meters per second (returned if available)
timestamp The date/time of the response (returned if available)

content.text: Geolocation Object - Other interesting Methods
The Geolocation object also has other interesting methods:
content.html: The Geolocation object also has other interesting methods:

content.text: The example below shows the watchPosition() method. You need an accurate GPS device to test this (like smartphone):
content.html: The example below shows the watchPosition() method. You need an accurate GPS device to test this (like smartphone):

syntaxHighlighting.text: "Geolocation is not supported by this browser."

syntax_highlighting.text: "Geolocation is not supported by this browser."

content.code_html:
<script>
const x = document.getElementById("demo");
function getLocation() {
  if (navigator.geolocation) {
    navigator.geolocation.watchPosition(showPosition);
  } else {
    x.innerHTML = "Geolocation is not supported by this browser.";
  }
}
function showPosition(position) {
  x.innerHTML = "Latitude: " + position.coords.latitude +
  "<br>Longitude: " + position.coords.longitude;
}
</script>

syntax_highlighting_data.text: "Geolocation is not supported by this browser."
